description:
Writing reviews for my 3 favorite Sightglass coffee shops. 

Video sketch on all 3 locations. 
youtu.be/CKyLAk5jzuQ

This location is in Mission/Dogpatch area. Compared to shops on Divisadero(medium) or 7th street(large), the space here is small size. A lot of people come and go in the morning, so sometimes you have to wait for a seat. Because it's not a large space, crowd is more quiet. 

The lighting, color, furniture, tile, etc.. give you a warm and special feeling and their design theme continues in other stores like the one on Divisadero. Again, I think their coffee and the thought they put in spatial design is on another level :) 

Stop here to get coffee and then you can head to Tartine Manufactory to grab pastry. (5min walk) Only negative thing is it's difficult to find parking.
author: Dee K.

description:
Coffee: Great and I like the simple menu where everything is amazing!

Prices: Reasonable for San Francisco.

Service: Super friendly and fast.

Atmosphere: Beautiful inside; wish they had more seating.

Location: In an up-and-coming portion of the Mission near a lot of cute shops and restaurants!
author: Michelle B.

description:
What a cute cute cute cafe that makes super good good good coffee located in an industrial area (is it really called Dog Patch?). It is within walking distance from Tartine Manufactury (wink, wink).

Ordered their Mocha and you could tell that dark chocolate was used.
author: Kislev A.

description: Great hipster coffee place and a popular location for all the Mission folks. There's almost always people hanging out inside and on the bench outside with Sightglass drinks. I have yet to try their regular coffees, but the vanilla cold brew was very smooth and refreshing, albeit a bit sweet for my tastes. The mocha is hands-down my favorite drink. The chocolate is bittersweet, so its not overwhelming sweet like the typical mocha's you would get. You can also easily substitute dairy with almond or soy milk as well. Each hot drink is made carefully and with some kind of heart-like latte art too :) Wait time might be a bit longer as they don't rush the process. Condiments and caps are located in a corner at the back of the store. Also they take NFC payments and tap cards.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Last stop in SF before heading to the airport. I believe we got the Ethiopian over ice, since they didn't have plain cold brew/iced coffee. Great bean recommendation by the barista! Theres a few seats inside but I don't think it's a great place to get work done.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
tldr; best coffee shop for meeting up or studying!

I went into this shop initially because the unique name of this coffee shop caught my eye. What I found was the perfect, aesthetic coffee shop (sadly no WiFi though :'( ) that had ample interior seating and great coffee. 

The coffee is fairy price (I got a latte for $4), and ambience is wonderful for being productive or quietly chatting with friends.

If I lived closer to this coffee shop, I would totally come here to work all the time! (on anything that didn't require WiFi, that is).
author: Cassie Z.

description: Great place to chill and have a cup of coffee and great tasting pasty, they roast their own coffee too and it is a great thing that you can sit and see the process.
author: Mehran A.

description:
Everything about Sightglass is literal coffee goals. I've heard about it many times from coffee folks, and have seen their beans served everywhere here in San Diego. I've finally visited it for the first time and was totally amused by it. 

Their aesthetics are on point, the elegant wooden coffee shop vibe with the honeycomb floors. Their coffee is great, and like I said earlier they have their beans for wholesale everywhere in California. It's almost a staple that good coffee is served here if you see Sightglass coffee beans. 

Not the biggest shop (I believe the one on 7th street is bigger with two floors), but everything about it screams SF. The baristas, the decor, the customers, you name it. You can tell they are passionate about their craft, and I absolutely love that. I would definitely come back with friends to try other items on their menu.
author: Ivan C.

description: It's a pastry life! Sightglass sources from my favorite neighborhood bakeries. And the coffee is delicious to boot. This is the ultimate neighborhood coffee joint.
author: Aakash G.

description: no iced coffee, no wifi, seating for like 4.25 people. Atlas is 100% better. Barista had an attitude which I guess is a job requirement, but geesh at least look up when a customer walks in.
author: Audrey I.

description:
Good coffee house in the Dog Patch neighborhood. Starbucks is good but lacks the uniqueness of places like this. 
Will return for its variety of coffees.
author: Gary Y.

description: What a treat to visit this Sightglass location!  I've had sightglass coffee at a couple of coffee shops at home in LA, and do love the coffee.  The shop is small with a great environment.  I got an almond latte which tasted great!  What was really exciting for me was that they have B Patisserie pastries!  During my short time in SF, I didn't think I would actually make it out the B Patisserie bakery, so I still got the glorious kougin aumin all at one place.  Success! :)
author: Meagan T.

description: Solid coffee, 'nuff said. I used to think four barrel was the gold standard but this place has really grown on me. And it does not feel snobby which is huge in my book!!
author: Rahul H.

description:
This place is also an in house toaster and it was pretty cool to watch. I love the decor and the seats. 

First of all, the coffee was good! I liked my cappuccino and the mocha was not too sweet (which I prefer). Wish that there would be a bit more chocolatey but it was good.

The coffeeshop itself is nicely decorated and has some seatings outside. There are not too many tables however. About 4-5 tables but there's more seatings area space. 

NOTE: this place DOES NOT HAVE WIFI!
author: Dream-Suphada L.

description: A little pricey, but delicious cappuccino and pistachio croissant with blackberry jam. Everything was beautiful in this location. All of the pastries were aesthetically, clearly labeled. This was my first time at this location (or at any Sightglass). I enjoyed my experience. I grabbed my croissant and cappuccino to go. They made a beautiful heart - the latte art/"coffee" sign in the floor tiles outside of the door are great for Instagram fodder. The cappuccino could've been a little bigger for the price, but I'll be back.
author: Zinia G.

description:
Expensive and very limited milk and sugar options.

They only offer: 
- whole milk, almond milk
- raw sugar

Why can't they offer soy/nonfat milk or stevia/splenda like a normal coffee shop?? I shouldn't have to pay $5 for a small coffee and still provide 2/3 of the ingredients.
author: A -.

description: Chill cafe. Iced coffee was delicious and packed a punch. Wooden curved bench seats along the wall was a unique design. Interior design was classy and the roof had a cool wooden panel design. But what's most important was the caffeine was on point.
author: De B.

description:
Heading out of SF! 

Ordered: cold brew 

Pros: it tasted delicious, there was milk and agave in it! The interior of this housing is very industrial with huge pretty windows! It's in a neat part of town.

Cons: they have no sweeteners not even honey which is fine if you don't care, but I think it's a pretty basic thing to offer. I would have loved a honey latte. This place is not for me although I did enjoy the interior.
author: Ceci F.

description: Wonderful interior, wish there was more space. Wonderful neighborhood. You can park your cycle outside and sip some fine coffee at peace. No WiFi so plan accordingly. Bay Area prices, but there's  style, expert baristas and good conversations to look forward to. I like their stance: cappuccino with whole milk and almond milk only. No other milk options.
author: Akhil K.

description: One of my favorite coffees in SF. And the environment is just as smooth as the coffee. Win win. A beautiful experience all around.
author: Justin J.

description: Expensive, but their house iced coffee and pastries are delicious and always worth going for.
author: Abby F.

description:
Love the location of this coffeeshop in the Mission. 

Interior is pretty small so there usually isn't any seating available.

Nice interior decor and signage. Love the illustration and design of the coffee cups.
author: Monica G.

description:
Cute space.

Their pastries looked good but I resisted.

I had an espresso con panna. Their whip is old-school with bits of vanilla bean. Delicious.

I saw photos of the vanilla cold brew and needed it in my life so I bought one. SO GOOD!!!!!!

They sell a few cool Brewing tools.

Well done!
author: Michelle C.

description:
Beautiful coffee shop, but very disappointing, and super expensive.  I think I paid $11 with tax for two cortados.  There just wasn't anything special about our drinks, other than the price ;) and the pastries were also overpriced compared to what you can get elsewhere.  Service was below average helpful--I'm a coffee nerd and love to get good info from a top place, but I didn't get much more here than glares.

That said, always appreciate coffeeshops that make water easily accessible.
author: Craig Z.

description:
Originally my review was going to be 1 star, but I have to give credit to a good coffee. 

However, if you're looking for a coffeeshop to do work, or have time to yourself, turn around and save yourself from a $4 coffee. This place DOES NOT HAVE WIFI, and the space is small with just 3 small tables. would be a good location to meet with a friend, but DEFINITELY not for doing work or have meetings. Save yourself the $$$ and walk yourself to Atlas Cafe - they have Stumptown for a dollar less, and free wifi.
author: Leah K.

description: Best decaf lattes ever. Don't hate on the decaf ppl! The coffee is so smooth and makes you feel some type of way. Lady with the purple lipstick, thanks for being nice to my child, you rock!
author: Cindy G.

description:
Got a coffee and chocolate croissant here and both were pretty good, prices are normal for a hipster san Francisco café so it was around 8 bucks total for both. It's a nice place to hang out with friends and chat, ample seating and clean venue. 

+1 star for a really clean bathroom!
author: Jon T.

description: The staff here is so lovely! The coffee is delicious. Great, light atmosphere. High ceilings, wood and metal, plants. Lots of dogs outside near the benches kn weekends.
author: Ryan E.

description: We are from Seattle, so you may consider us coffee snobs..& this place is really decent! I would definitely go here again. We tried multiple other coffee places around San Fran during our visit and this was my favorite.
author: Erin M.

description:
I have been a fan of Sightglass ever since I visited one of their SOMA location several years ago.  At the time, I remember thinking they served high quality coffee in a beautifully designed setting.

After lunch one day, I ended up looking for coffee to try to combat the post-lunch slump, and to my delight I saw that there was a Sightglass nearby.  I've been there a few times now, and while I am still a fan of their espresso (usually gotten as an Americano), I am really impressed by their vanilla cold brew.  It comes with milk already added (you can choose whole or almond milk), and I found it had an excellent vanilla flavor without being overly sweet.  The barista advised me that adding almond milk might make it too sweet, so just keep that in mind when you order.  The cafe is also filled with lots of wooden furniture and sunlight, which makes me think it would be a good space to linger and get some work done or have a long chat with a friend.

One minor downside is that the staff is somewhat aloof, but otherwise, I'll definitely be back for the good brew and the excellent space!
author: Keith H.

description: Nothing special about this place at all. Just another SF hipster joint. I came here expecting to get some work done and guess what. No wi-fi, no outlets! BOO!! Lamest coffee shop ever. I found this out after ordering a vanilla cold brew (which actually doesn't have a strong flavor for $4.50). Anyways, this place is def not a good place to get work done - I ended up going to Starbucks where I had to buy something else in there to be a kind person and not just freeload the wifi and seating area. Im not sure why this place is so highly rated - it really is nothing special. The only things I liked about the place was the hipster words "Coffee" spelled out of tile on the ground and the logo on the cup. But that's definitely not enough to send me back here.
author: Anna L.

description:
Very cozy, chill and quiet coffee shop. I actually really like it. I really like the neighborhood they are located in as well. A few tables and seats inside. One long bench outside, super nice to sit on a sunny day. They have baked goods from a few bakeries in the city, such as neighbor bakehouse. Yum. Also the staff was very friendly.

I got their latte with almond milk. For a latte, it was pretty strong which was great. Need that boost after lunch. Not my favorite coffee spot in the city but its worth a visit if you're in the area. Also got some beans to go for my best friend. She is from KS, she will love it.
author: Sandy B.

description:
Hard not to give 5 stars since I love having them as part of our neighborhood, the coffee quality is stellar, the atmosphere relaxed and beautiful, the staff always welcoming and friendly. Sure, it's more expensive than hitting up Philz or Atlas, but the minor price differential has always seemed worth it for all the loves stated above.

But a couple of days ago I got a couple of quick cups and a croissant and the damage was $15.50. Granted $2 of that was tip, but that made me do a double-take. It looks like the last time I had a Sightglass quick cup was July 4 - and it was $3.50. Doing some digging online and Thrillest posted an article in Feb 2016 on where to get a great cup of coffee in SF for under $3 and had Sightglass was listed for serving up their quick cups for $2.50. Today it's $4.75 per quick cup and I've having a hard time reconciling the 36% increase from a mere three months ago. Especially considering that a cappuccino is $4.50 and a latte $5, both of which require longer time to prepare and more labor on the side of the staff. $4.75 for pre-prepared batch drip coffee, dispensed from an urn in about 5 seconds makes little sense. 

That all being said, I shared my thoughts directly with sightglass and a manager was very considerate in replying with understanding the original frustration, some thinking behind their decision-making (primarily to support the minimum wage increase in SF, which is certainly warranted), and their goal to keep more accessible (both in price and flavor) coffees available in the quick cup rotation.
author: Liz F.

description: Gonna keep this review short and sweet. I don't live or work near a Sightglass but if I did, I would be there all the time. Sightglass Coffee is your quintessential local SF coffee shop. Glass windows, overcast but bright light pouring through the windows, friendly hipster barista, and delicious coffee. I learned today that all of Sightglass coffees are light (no dark roasts) but that does not cut back the flavor at all. My go-to drink is always a latte. Sightglass is one of my favs for SF coffee!
author: Grace J.

description: Good coffee in a pretty space. Which basically describes a lot of coffee shops around here. Kitty corner to the shop are some planter boxes which also make for some good sittin'
author: Misha T.

description: Coffee is pretty good, although it's a bit pricey for the size. Interactions with the baristas were very transactional and they didn't seem particularly friendly. However, what I was most disappointed by was the lack of wifi and outlets here. I'm genuinely surprised that a coffee shop in this day and age doesn't even provide internet access for its guests. While the environment is great for conversations and casual meet ups, there is absolutely no way to have a productive afternoon here.
author: Amy C.

description:
This Sightglass location is not as impressive architecturally as its SoMa brother, but I actually like this one more. It's tucked into the border between Mission and Potrero Hill, so you get more of an intimate residential vibe. No one is in a rush, and everyone is friendly. They even have a cute (IG-worthy) tiled welcome "mat" at the front door. 

I've only ever had the latte here (which is smooth and fantastic), but I've heard delightful things about the vanilla cold brew with almond milk -- I'll definitely try that the next time I visit.
author: Christine L.

description:
2 stars for the bathroom. That was nice. Big & clean!
The cafe itself, yes very nice space, but I have a feeling these days these places are just there to celebrate the architect and interior designer...I mean the counter is huge but there are only 3 small tables or so to sit down...And yes, it is build with the intention to appeal to all the millennials and hipsters---Oh San Francisco you have changed so much :(
The cappuccino took 15 minutes to make (no there was NO line). The pastries are the same you would get at Whole Foods...
If anyone knows of cosy cafes left in SF please let me know. I'm so tired of the hipster/trendy thing...it's actually too mainstream these days.
author: Ana M.

description:
Usually visit the one in Soma, so I gave this location a try

Pros:
- great coffees
- typical SF hipster as hell coffee shop
- kind staff

Cons:
- seating is pretty limited

Ordered a V60 pour over and an iced vanilla cold brew. They didn't disappoint! Freshly brewed coffee means great flavors and aromas. Iced Cold Brew was not too sweet and overpowering. They also got a really cute tile floor design. Would come again if in the area!
author: Brian L.

description:
Sightglass has got to b my favorite coffee in all of California. (probably more than the other popular Blue Bottle Coffee.) they harvest n roast their own beans. the flavors r always robust n wickedly aromatic. every time I'm in San Francisco, I feel like I need to get a cup of latte at Sightglass. 

this location in the Mission area is quite small compared to their other spacious main store. whenever I go there, there's always a need to c if anyone is leaving so that we can grab some seats fast! there is only a bench along the wall n one outside the front door for customers to sit, so it's more of a buy n leave kinda coffee shop. it's still the cutest little place tho. the high ceiling with its airy n modern clean look sets the perfect mood for coffee lovers alike. 

they also have great tasting pastries. I think they get those from a local bakery. Mast Bros. chocolates can also b bought at the front counter!

did y'all c my lovely Latte art below??? no idea which fruit it is, but MIND-BLOWN.
author: Julie W.

description:
Sightglass is a must stop for coffee lovers who visit San Francisco! The interior design makes for an amazing ambiance while your sipping away at your espresso or one of their many different pour over.

Just a heads up; if your planning on bringing some work to do while your here, there isn't a ton of seating so you might be waiting a little bit for a seat to free up like us but it was well worth it.

Their pasty selection is also to die for!
author: Ryan S.

description:
First charmed by the beautiful photos I came here for a brief layover until I met with friends at a bar. I walked past another coffee shop and stuck to my route to this location because it looked great.  

I ordered house coffee and a chocolate crossaint. The simple house brewed coffee is worse than your local diners. It had a strange sour taste I've never experienced in coffee before, leaving me to gag at the taste. The chocolate crossaint was supposed to be my savior, instead it left me asking why and how does this abomination of a version to a simple sweet treat exist. There a two horizontal bricks of chocolate that run parallel towards the bottom of the dry, stale croissant. I couldn't finish either and urged my friends to hurry because I was done with this overrated white hipster spot. A shiny package with garbage inside.
author: Rabiah K.

description: Not much seating, and like all Sightglass locations, no wifi. But worth visiting for the sole fact that it is imo the most beautiful cafe in SF! Interior is absolutely stunning
author: Michelle C.

description: The coffee here is great and I like the vibe here. The only two things I don't prefer are that the tables are bolted to the ground so if I work on the table, I'm leaning forward and super hunched over, and the music is really loud here. I won't come back to get work done, BUT I will be back to get a good cup of coffee and to catch up with friends.
author: Angie Y.

description: Exceptionally good coffee flavor profiles, not too acidic - like some other popular SF coffee roaster, I love the fact that they also have space at MOMA.  Always nice to be able to take a break after purusing the galleries.
author: Brian S.

description: Hands down Blueboon is my favorite coffee in the City. Decent espresso, but Blueboon keeps me coming back.
author: Johnathan K.

description: I came to sightglass coffee during the first week Pokemon Go launched, so my experience here was very short lived, but still a good one. It was hard to find street parking, but we finally found a spot about 2-3 blocks over. Normally this would've been frustrating, but we had nothing to do and the extra blocks to walk just meant more time to catch pokemon. When we arrived, I loved the characteristic teal building and cute floor adorned with "coffee." The barista was super sweet and we ordered their vanilla cold brew to go. It's definitely one of my favorite cold brews out there. Aromatic, strong, just enough vanilla, it's a good time. I will definitely have to come back here to stay inside to study because the interior looked beautiful. We took our cold brews and walked around the mural heavy neighborhood, which if you have the time, I suggest you check out too!
author: Maleah M.

description: My friends were visiting SF and their first stop was here.  I don't quite get the hype, but this place is pretty cute.  The lattes were good, it was brewed perfectly. I'm usually scared that it will be too sour for my liking.   The place is kind of small and there were limited seats.  They have about 4 tables here and a bench outside.  I was lucky enough to find a table.  This place is a nice shop to come and just chat with your friends, It's also a quite place for you to come and do some reading or studying.   The building shares the same location as other shops so the restroom is shared among the other stores too.   I wish they had a better system when picking up your drink, because i wasn't able to hear them call us, even though the place wasn't that loud with customers.
author: Belinda C.

description: Probably the nicest coffee shop I've ever been to, and I've been to quite literally almost every coffee shop worth visiting between SF and LA. Needless to say, the coffee is great but the interior is what stands out the most to me. It's clearly intentional and every single detail is stunning. The customer service was good, and the surrounding area is really pretty. Parking is difficult, but where is it not downtown?
author: Joseph K.

description: Lovely lattes and pastries. My 2 stars is for my experience yesterday when I wanted to buy some beans for home. I very specifically asked for a roast that is dark, nutty, and NOT fruity or acidic. I stated "I really don't care for African coffees." The barista picked out a bag and swore it was what I'd described. Brewed this morning and noticed overwhelming fruit/acid notes. And now I'm out $19. Looked at the description online and it states that it is blended WITH Ethiopian beans. Last I knew, Ethiopia was in Africa. Please train your staff to better know the coffee they are recommending.
author: Chris S.

description:
With the coffee competition being so fierce in this city, your brew really needs to deliver on all levels to set itself apart.  What you bring to the table has to be different & striking, otherwise it's superfluous.  Because, quite frankly, San Francisco's coffee table is already full.

If I could drink the aesthetic here, I'd be very happy.  

The space is modern & simple.  Cool, clean, & comfortable.  And it's the space that I came away w an appreciation for, rather than for the coffee.  

Maybe it's me.  Maybe my coffee palate has become desensitized from all the artisan coffee joints I frequent on the daily.  But I honestly did not taste anything better here than I get at Blue Bottle, or Four Barrel, or Ritual.  Or Andytown.  Or Philz.  And I can't forget about the old school joints like Trieste & Graffeo.  And Illy.  They continue to deliver a supreme brew, consistently, still after all of these years.  

Great space.  Good pastries.  Good coffee.

3 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
20th Street location is nice, smaller, cozier and shadier than the Folsom one. The vibe is more serene and laid back than the seriousness and work-oriented atmosphere at SOMA. Limited seating space with some benches right outside.

Coffee is solid. Love the almond milk cold brew! Not too sweet, nutty and refreshing. While I prefer Blue Bottle, if you're really looking for great espresso-based drinks go to the Heath Ceramics Blue Bottle. Honestly, what sways me towards going to Sightglass are the pastries they source from b. patisserie or Neighbor Bakehouse which I haven't seen at many other coffeeshops.
author: Truc N.

description:
This place is the following things:

- Ultra trendy
- Minimalistic (in terms of both their menu and decor)
- Hard to find parking for
- Staffed by people trendier than you'll ever be

I like a place that does a few things well, rather than many things just okay. I didn't particularly love my latte, but the guy was a fan of their cold brew, and there seem to be a good many coffee snobs flocking here, adorned in yoga gear with mats sticking out of their satchels. If that's your scene, you should definitely come here.
author: Claire S.

description:
Meh. A much smaller space than the original SoMa showcase, this Sightglass branch has only a few seats and has a retro/vintage feel to it. Moreover, without the atmospherics of the SoMa location, you quickly hone in on the fact that the coffee isn't anywhere near as memorable as that of, say, Ritual or Blue Bottle. 

Nevertheless, another good addition to the neighborhood.
author: Vincent L.

description: Their iced vanilla almond milk coffee is my favorite!! Gets me through the day! Super cute inside! Quality coffee!
author: Brittni G.

description: awesome location in a quite part of mission district.  it is spacious and quiet.  coffee is always good and people are nice and cool.  pastries from b patisserie which is an extra plus.  cool and comfortable seats to take care of some work or business.
author: Linda T.

description:
Oh of the best made-to-order coffee spots in SF.  Such high quality beans that are roasted daily and always fresh.  Excellent slow drip coffee and espresso drinks.  Coffee selections change daily - which just speaks to how fresh/new their beans are!

Baked goods are also delicious; my girlfriend is obsessed with their ginger cookies (made with real ginger).

And their cups are so adorable!  As is the ambiance in 20th street location.  You can't help but be happy sipping on your cup of joe :)
author: Rachael S.

description:
It was nice Sunny day in SF slightly windy, and I needed a pick me up. My friend had an interview to do at this spot so I figured I'll tag along and grab a nice delicious cup of coffee. 

The spot has a very OPEN space type of vibe. Very Hipster but on the more gentrified side of things if you know what I mean. =P 

I ordered a normal pour over from the barista. After getting the drink, my drink tasted slightly burnt.. I added some sugar to try and over power it but it was ehh. I sat down with my friend while there talking and I was eavesdropping the crap out of them. But this next thing surprised me. I asked for the wifi, and surprisingly they don't have free wifi. I was quite shocked. I mean call me cheap and asian, but I'm on a data plan I pay for it like an adult. So saving money in any circumstances is something I'll try to take advantage every time. What if I had a laptop webcam session with little Akube from Africa ?

But we also gotta keep in mind that this coffee spot is probably just trying to get their customers in and out, which is a shame, because it's a very nice spot to study, converse, etc. 

I might come back to try their signature drink, other than that, you guys get 3 stars my friend.
author: Huy H.

description:
Cute café close to the Mission Cliffs gym where my boyfriend and I go climbing. I love coming to Sightglass because the baristas are so friendly and the coffee is amazing. Great place to get some reading done or catch up with a friend.

I always opt for a latte as I'm sitting and enjoying the terrariums and other lovely decor that makes me feel zen and immersed in nature. Sightglass locations are always so spacious and relaxing! Definitely would recommend as one of my favorite cafés in the city.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
This place is the height of sf coffee. Milling machines, single origin varietals, industrial loft atmosphere, its all here

This is serious coffee for connoisseurs. If u bring their ethiopian coffee to tokyo (where they *know* coffee) you will likely earn some points. It will give your baggage a rich coffee scent too.
author: Philip L.

description:
I stopped by this location of Sightglass Coffee while waiting for Trick Dog to open up next door.  This was actually my first time visiting any Sightglass Coffee shop, so I wanted to make sure that I ordered something that their known for.  

Like my first time at Philz with their Jamaican Blue Mountain, I went with the most expensive cup they offered, the Finca Monte Verde Geisha ($7 /cup).  I had my coffee straight up and it was really good!  Didn't have the need for any cream or sugar.  It had a subtle sweetness but was also strong enough that you felt energized after a few sips.  I'm not a coffee connoisseur so I can't really break it down in terms of flavors but overall the coffee is good.  

The location is pretty nice too and shares the same building with Trick Dog, Salumeria, and Central Kitchen, all of which share the same restrooms.  

I wouldn't say Sightglass my favorite coffee in SF, but I wouldn't mind going back for another cup.  And with this location being next to Trick Dog which I frequently visit, it's highly likely I'll be back again.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Amazing cappuccino - it's almost decadent. Great music choices too. 

While space is very light and airy and very welcoming! I love the high ceilings.
author: Megan R.

description:
I'm lucky enough to work on 20th street. Most of my officemates head to Atlas for their coffee needs, but I'm a devoted Sightglass drinker. The iced coffees, and the occasionally served nitro coffee, is really good. Strong, and good.

Recently, I tried a pastry. Now I'm not sure if I'll ever be able to order a coffee without also getting one! I had the everything croissant with cream cheese and it was fantastic. Like an everything bagel, but for days when you're feeling fancier and like consuming more butter. I also have my eyes on the cheddar and sauerkraut pastry. The sweet ones look great too, and I know my colleagues have given the cookies good reviews.

I love the decor, too, and appreciate the feel of the place. Definitely makes a little coffee break feel like more of a break.
author: Maria M.

description:
PSA: no wifi here! So frustrating to come to a cafe expecting to get work done only to find out that there is no wifi along with very limited seating. 
Lack of wifi aside, this coffee shop definitely stands out in my book. The unique ambience, and pastries from B-patisserie all mesh together to create a fantastic coffee shop experience. I broke away from my usual cappuccino and ended up getting a chocolate raspberry scone. It was the perfect combination of sweet and sour. My friend ordered an Italian soda. It came in a cute canning jar with a handle. The drink itself was a bit strange. It started out almost vinegary on top, getting sweeter towards the bottom where the syrup had settled. While a bit unusual, I appreciate the unique offerings at this cafe. I will definitely be back. When I don't need to get work done, that is.
author: Mikowai A.

description:
I never thought I would say this but I think the Vanilla Toddy ($4 - vanilla paste, agave, coffee) ranks up there with Philz iced mint mojito. 

Their mocha sounded decadent but was mediocre. They use hookers chocolate ganache but the richness was lost in the milk, perhaps they didn't use enough or used too high percentage of chocolate? 

They have some limited but cute cafe seating, and a variety of delicious looking pastries. Hats off to whoever curated the selection and decorated the inside. The service is typical Mission nose in the air. All credit cards accepted.
author: Jess C.

description:
I've always been enchanted with the idea of spending the day in a coffee shop--what could be better then a day spent reading (okay, people watching) and slowly sipping coffee? Unfortunately, for a long time every coffee shop I tried had some quality that precluded my actually wanting to spend more than an hour there: cold, dirty tables, bad coffee, loud atmosphere, etc. After trying Sightglass, I am happy to say that this Goldilocks has found a coffee shop that is just right.

Sightglass (which I always accidentally call "Shotglass"...oops?) is clean, comfortable, not too loud, and has great coffee. I highly recommend the vanilla cold brew, which I got with almond milk. It wasn't cheap, but the portion was generous and delicious. Sightglass is understandably very popular, so try to get there earlier in the day if you want to snag a table and camp out for a bit. I hear great things about their pastries as well, but have yet to try any, so you try one for me and let me know how you liked it!
author: Neha S.

description:
Hey!
I'm a huge coffee fan 
The design on the coffee looked super awesome 
If ur a coffee lover like me u should try it
And they make their own coffee which I think is really cool
It came out pretty fast btw
And it's fairly priced
author: Leticia L.

description: Believe or not, I learned of sightglass coffee in New York while visiting Bluestone Lane coffee, a coffee shop that serves Australian style coffee, flat white, short black, etc. I was so interested about the beans that the barista informed me that they get it from SF, a small roasters called sightglass coffee. I was sold after that and it has been a couple of years that I've frequently visited this shop since then. The coffee is consistent, I've ordered drip, espresso, French press, etc. And it always good, and I like the staff layback attitude. Great beans, and consistent flavor in their roast. I would recommend their medium roast variety where you can taste the true character of the beans.
author: Ben P.

description:
Great space. Like Restoration Hardware married the Pottery Barn.

The staff was friendly, and I got my latte rather quickly.

They even do a small design, from what my friends and I received, it all seemed to be a leaf motif.

I wonder if like those balloon artists, they could do custom foam drawings. Like if I paid them a dollar or two, could they draw me a squirrel? Or the Golden Gate Bridge out of foam?

Now that would be cool.
author: Jack R.

description: Great ambience, fantastic customer service, delicious food. My friend ordered iced vanilla coffee and I tried vanilla cold brew which I find great. I had just a little sip of what he tried and thought it was mediocre. I truly enjoyed my visit here. I will definitely come back.
author: Natasha R.

description: I was already a little mediocre on Sightglass, and in going to their Mission establishment, my sentiment continues.  While the Costa Rican pourover I had was good, it took an extraordinary long time to get my coffee.  I'm generally a patient person, especially when it comes to pourovers, but the baristas who were making the coffees seemed to take the phrase 'Sunday stroll' quite literally.  I love the space, especially all of the wonderful natural light, big windows, and the tiled 'Coffee' doormat that welcomes you, but other than that, I found myself having a hard time enjoying my experience.  There isn't a ton of seating either, so be prepared to share a long wooden table with some new friends. Overall, I  thought the whole experience was generally OK when you consider the other options that are in the area.
author: Lisa I.

description:
This was the coffee shop that made me fall for fancy coffees in San Francisco. Then I found the Blue Bottle two blocks away, and now I rotate between the two.
While I would take tourists to the Sightglass downtown, this is the Sightglass I end up at the most. It shares its location with other hipster-y places: Salumeria, Trick Dog, and Central Kitchen.

The seating is awkward and there's never quite enough: it mostly consists of a single bench that snakes around a few tables. Stylish, but limited. If you want to sit down inside, expect to be at a table with someone else. There are also a few wooden benches outside.
They've successfully made it feel weird to be on your computer, so I wouldn't recommend going there to work. Maybe a short break to read while sipping coffee, but even that's pushing it with the crowds.

The pastries are suspiciously similar to the other coffee places. The pistachio scone is my current favorite. My previous favorite was the hazelnut orange cake, which was usually awesome, but was once very bad.

My favorite thing here is the cappuccino. It comes in a very tiny cup, but it's so tasty that I don't even mind the size.
I've tried a few of their other drinks, but the cappuccino is the one that keeps me coming back.
author: Jessica S.

description:
I'm a HUGE fan of Sightgass Coffee and I actually didn't realize that there was more than one location here in San Francisco. I usually frequent the cafe over in SOMA.

Concerning this particular location, it was a little too small considering how much business they receive. The seating was very limited and I wound up having to stand in order to sip my macchiato and munch on my chocolate chip cookie. 

Otherwise, the coffee was on par, staff was friendly and efficient; I just wish my lazy arse could've had a seat to sit in. 

I love that the pastry selection is vast, but equally a winner. You seriously can't go wrong with any selection you decide to go with. My faves include the sugar brioche and coffee cake!

Hurrah hurrah for Sightglass Coffee! I'll just pack my lawn chair for next time!
author: Ann S.

description:
During my last visit I asked the barista to expound on the pour over du jour and received well informed profiles - hints, flavors, including a V60 vs Chemex recommendation.

Five Stars!
author: James G.

description: Coming from Chicago a medium size cup for $5 and some change was pretty pricey hence my 4-stars but the coffee and service was great!
author: Amanda M.

description:
Hidden in the Mission around a residential neighborhood, Sightglass is a gem for coffee enthusiasts. With a purely no nonsense coffee menu and delicious treats such as cookies, brownies, and scones, Sightglass doesn't joke around about coffee. 

Walking in, I saw the pourover set up and espresso machines. Since I always order pourovers, I wanted to try something else for once. The barista recommended the vanilla ice cold brew, and it was one of the best iced coffees I have ever had. I dislike coffee drinks that are too sweet, but after being a little wary, I tried it, and it was not too sweet! The vanilla added a perfect milky taste to the iced coffee. This milky rather than sweet taste is rare, so I will definitely come back for this drink again. 

Sightglass is one of the best coffee shops in the nation, and after I tried it, I don't doubt what other reviews have said about this place.
author: Annie C.

description: I stop by Sightglass every other day as my office is on the same block. Love the space and design, light and airy, also great pastries. Coffee is tasty as I personally like light/medium roast. But what does my head in sometimes is its temperature, I know there is a fine line, but lukewarm cappuccino is a shitty cappuccino in my world.
author: Marina T.

description: I love this neighborhood when I visitSan Francisco.  I'm already a long-standing fan of Sightglass and this second location has a great neighborhood feel.  Prepare to share tables because this is smaller than the one on 7th.  There are less Macbooks flipped open here so more chances to interact with whoever you find yourself sitting next to!
author: Trish S.

description:
Sightglass seems to be getting better and better lately.
I've been stopping here after work.
This location is nice and mellow in the late afternoon.

The pour-over coffee has been exceptional.
I got a cup of the Guatemala Cubito and it was about as delicious as fresh single origin coffee can be. It was right in the sweet spot of being bright and clear without being sour while retaining a classic coffee texture/body. 
Perfect decaf latte too.

Beautiful cafe. Highest quality coffee. Simple and no BS. 
They're starting to outpace Blue Bottle in flavor.
author: RK W.

description: i am very dissapointed !!!coffee tasted watery no coffee flavor at all!!!!  pastries nothing exciting not coming back !!
author: Cecilia C.

description:
I was surprised by how much I liked this place, and it was not based on coffee alone. We came here the morning of this past weekend's Bay to Breakers to start the day off, not planning to run but still did walk all the way to Ocean Beach, so we needed a jolt.

I ordered a Hooker's Mocha, plus a Coffee Cake. The beverage wasn't too sweet, very delectable, and had a beautiful design with the foam/cream pattern. What's more astounding was my coffee cake -- this was the freshest, best-tasting pastry I've had in who-knows-how-long. Not your typical run of the mill coffee cake, this one had a surprise inside: peaches!

Now that I've stopped drooling, I can finish my review. There wasn't too much room to sit, but we got our orders to go anyway -- we still had eleven miles ahead of us! Regardless, for creatively-titled beverages and/or scrumptiously fresh pastries (huge selection to choose from), for here or to go, Sightglass could be very worthwhile.
author: Garett T.

description:
Nice alternative to their 7th st. location.

Love the Vanilla Cold Brew.

Worth visiting even just to check out the interior design.
author: Yohdaddy M.

description:
The coffee here is impeccable. I trekked out to this location as the husband requested some beans from here for his birthday (and since we live in a diff state, this tells you about the quality of this coffee!). 
It only took me almost 30 min to park. And I gave up trying to find anything nearby and parked many blocks away. It's pretty insane. That's why I don't think I'll ever come out to this location unless I'm in the area.
author: Aletheia W.

description:
Sightglass coffee has always been one of my favs. this spot is hard to find parking for. menu: coffee, latte, pastries, beans

brew: 12 oz brew(2)
-very smooth, not both, just easy sipping

drips:
-in and out in minutes
-a few tables available for sitdown.
author: Victor G.

description:
This place is my No.1 cafe in San Francisco!!
As one of the best third wave coffee roasters, coffee drinks are amazing. I prefer cappuccino, the perfect blend of formed milk and dark espresso.

Actually bluebottle's iced coffee is the best drink for me, however in terms of the interior and atmosphere, Sightglass is the best. Modern combination of wood and metal make this place both cool and relaxing. I wish I could make my room like this...

Additionally the coffee goods they sell are mostly Japanese products! I'm always really happy to see that. I hope they open the shop in Tokyo like bluebottle did this year!
author: Rika N.

description: Quant little coffee shop with a calm atmosphere, tasty coffee and a nice selection of pastries. I shared an iced coffee with my GF and enjoyed the calming sound of their baristas and coffee roaster. they have a few tables inside and a bench outside, not a ton of space to stand when you're in line either. it looks like an old time doctors office. it's tucked away behind some trees if you're walking up Alabama but try not to miss out!
author: Mario C.

description: Sightglass coffee is one of our favorites. Their location in the mission is more of a stop in and run out kind of place with minimal seating. Their location off Folsom is much more thrilling with the high ceilings and industrial design. Love the coffee and cookies! Try their iced vanilla cold brew with almond milk.
author: Thom And Vicky H.

description:
Always great coffee. The pour over at Sightglass is their specialty. Given the size of the 20th st. location, it's sometimes hard to find a seat. 

The staff is friendly and they always have good music playing in the background. The design of the space is beautiful and worth the trip.
author: Brian H.

description: Beautiful interior. A bit too much on the hipster coffee shop aesthetics imo. And despite the high end vintage looking audio system the staff was playing music from a laptop. The pastry selection is excellent - tho it's on the pricey side.
author: Ruben K.

description: My friend and I had a bit of downtime and ended up at Sightglass, despite the fact that he's a noted third-wave hater (who for some reason has every possible piece of brewing equipment in his cubicle). Although we love the space and as out-of-towners we thought the gear they sold was pretty cute...we were not huge fans of the coffee. I had the vanilla bean iced coffee -- in theory, the vanilla would be a nice touch except that I couldn't taste it, and overall, it felt a bit more watery. Ditto on his Ethiopian pour-over.
author: Heidi L.

description: Came here for coffee on Sunday. I like the ambience of the place and that it is not in a very busy part of the SF. We had had the vanilla iced coffee, mocha, macchiato and expresso which were all very good. Also like the design of the cups:)
author: Qianqi L.

description:
After reading about the first location of Sightglass, having multiple friends and colleagues in the coffee world speak nothing but positivity about the brand and product, and hearing about the new 20th St location, I was pumped to have some downtime before flying back home. 

First off, the location is just gorgeous. Sparse seating, gorgeous layout of the a rather long bar, modern shelving, and tons of natural light. It's also a rather high ceiling so you don't get the feeling of being cramped into some small coffee den waiting for your whisper of Kopi Luwak or something fancy and unmentionable. 

The coffee is stellar. The care and consideration that Sightglass puts into their program is second to none. The enthusiasm and careful relationships these guys form with suppliers in other countries and also with their wholesale product is just wonderful. They exude everything I could want in a coffee shop -- passion for the product with a focus on love. 

To add on to growing pile of awesome, they implore their customers to utilize more preferred methods of brewing -- v60, Chemex, Aeropress, syphon, etc. Much appreciated and I love that they even have literature and methodology resources for each. 

I love you, Sightglass. Also, thanks for the bag of Ethiopian. Just amazing.
author: Benjamin G.

description:
Delicious coffee! Sightglass is one of the good local coffee shops, and I often just get it via other cafes or restaurants. I did enjoy my latte from here (well, much better than Starbucks but not as good as Blue Bottle) -- and they have quite a few good food/snack selections as well.

There is quite a bit of space and some tables outside as well. However, as usual, you will have to fight with the people that are working on their laptops for a space; so I'd recommend getting the coffee to go just in case. Plus, there's a salumeria right next door -- you can take your coffee there if you are just ordering a sandwich.
author: Alice C.

description:
Beautiful space that's delivering what one would expect from a decent coffee shop these days - great coffee, option of pour-over or drip, some smugness and cold-brew. 

At first I was turned off by the fact that they don't offer cold-brew unflavored. Worried about being too close-minded I took the risk and was delighted by the agave sweetened surprise - now I'm trying to recreate this in my own concoction. I highly recommend.

It's worth the trip down 20th, like most places on those few blocks are.
author: Marcus C.

description:
The coffee was good, as expected. 
This is a smaller Sightglass, I believe the other one is bigger one.
It has several restaurants/bars nearby, so you can also check them out.
Parking wasn't the best but, hey, you are in city. Plus, they close at 7 pm so plan accordingly.
author: Kate L.

description:
Randomly came here for coffee with my buddy. Ordered and iced latte, and I actually didn't have to adjust it at all. Was the right amount of sweetness for me. Quite honestly, it didn't blow me away, but it was solid.

What compelled me to review was mostly the pastries. Got a gluten free almond cake thing, a peanut butter cookie, and a lime-raspberry coconut macaron. The almond cake thing had this weird Play-Doh after-taste. Was so odd. Def. never getting that again. The peanut cookie was tough. Literally. It was a very hard and stiff cookie. Good crunch, I guess? Not up there with my fav. cookies. The macaron basically saved everything for me. That shit was so good. Hint of citrus, and coconut, and just the right amount of raspberry flavor. If I didn't buy the last one, I could've eaten like 3 more of them. So, good.

Was very limited seating. And for a Sunday mid-day stop, don't plan on sticking around to enjoy your drink there because it was a little busy, and people were posted up on their laptops inside the shop. There's some benches outside, but again, very limited.

If I'm in the hood again, I wouldn't mind coming here again, if anything just for that macaron.
author: Shawn B.

description: This place has a very nice modern feel to it and is pretty spacious for a coffee shop. What I really like about it is that they also offer individual brews. They also keep their menu short and simple. That day I tried their mocha which isn't your typical mocha, you get a nice rich chocolate flavor but it's not sweet. I enjoyed it because mochas are usually too sweet for me. Also a plus cause they have beautiful latte art. They even do it for you in to go cups. I haven't tried their regular brews. I thought their coffee was average. It didn't stand out to me. You have to find street parking which can get difficult in that area, so making a trip here can be a hassle. I would come back if it was closer or if I'm in the area and need some coffee. Otherwise, there's closer coffee spots for me.
author: Stephanie L.

description: This is the place to go if you want to wait 15 minutes for a cappuccino. All they have is whole milk and almond milk. And their pastries are awful - I've tried nearly all of them.
author: Jessica P.

description: Not nearly the size of the SOMA one but still great nonetheless. The owners McIntosh sound system is alone worth checking out of you're a audio geek. So are the double LaMarzocco Stradas that make the espresso. It was a warm day and so we decided on the vanilla toddy. Iced caffeine with something something to make it a bit on the sweeter side. Refreshing and caffeinating! Told one of the baristas about our friends love of Stradas and how she'd pet them if she saw them. Got a good laugh and some coffee geekism in there too.
author: Kim N.

description:
I must say, I do enjoy this place. The service is friendly. The "quick cup" is less than $3. The scones are delectable. 

There are cool looking hipsters reading old looking books. They like to position themselves right in front so you can see them and how cool they look and how old the books are.
author: Sabrina M.

description:
We frequent Chromatic Coffee and consider it to be the best in the Bay Area, but were curious to try Sightglass while in the city on business.

It was a sunny afternoon and quiet when we arrived. Our Barista was friendly and efficient. The coffee was very good, but fell a bit short of our usual experience at Chromatic (perhaps this is due to personal taste). 

I needed to use my laptop to prepare for my afternoon meeting and was disappointed at the lack of electrical outlets. I admit the charming ambiance would have suffered from many computers and over crowding, however.

Overall, our experience was very pleasant and I will certainly pay another visit the next time I need to go into the city.
author: Royce M.

description:
Narrower vision.

Expansive beginnings: http://www.yelp.com/biz/sightglass-coffee-san-francisco?hrid=YiAP4Eg6H3AeaUy7QUR1rA

Smaller sibling: Was surprised to find only four or five tables to sit. Fortunately we grabbed one and made ourselves comfortable against the leather cushioned seats.

Was also surprised to discover $2 coffee is a 2012 relic.  Now $7+ for a smooth decaf Kenyan blend drip and a quite good iced coffee with vanilla sweetener. Steal before. Standard now.

Market rate pricing didn't detract from an otherwise friendly staff (even when asking and being told no on skim milk) and a relaxing space assuming you can get a seat.

See four stars.
author: Jason B.

description:
You know that feeling when you find a gem in the haystack? That is the feeling you will get when you find Sightglass in the Mission. =)

Tucked away in an unmarked Forest/Bluish Green storefront with black numbers "3014" strewed along the left of the front door, the only other clues that you have arrived will be people lounging around on the patio bench (perhaps) with coffee and snacks in hand. If you know where Salumeria and Central Kitchen is, Sightglass is on the same block and approximately 2 doors to the left.

The beautiful interior has exposed woods, penny tiles, modern, simplistic whites with flower branches and glass pastry displays.

Find the tiny clipboard menu on the counter and place your order with the barista.

The coffee was excellent! I had the latte and kale turnover. The coffee was much more nutty and flavorful than Four Barrel, and yet not as fruity as Blue Bottle. The turnover was light and fluffy as well. The pastry selection also included one of my favorites - kouign amann from B. Patisserie.

Seating is limited, so be prepared to share communal tables/seating with other coffee aficionados.
author: Grace G.

description: Vanilla iced cold brew forever. The best!
author: DeAnna C.

description: Excellent coffee and delicious pastries served to you by surly and entitled hipster douchebags. Enjoy!
author: Ragazzobiondo ..

description:
Definitely one of my favorite roasters in the City.  Amazing espressos and cold brews.  The Baristas here know their craft and they take it very seriously.

My espressos are generally very clean on the initial taste with a very balanced aftertaste (i know it really depends on the seasonals) but generally a very good espresso.

Coffees aside, I feel very claustrophobic in there and I've never really gotten a chance to sit down because the seats are always taken.  Which isn't necessarily bad because I can take my drink and walk around the Mission ;)

Definitely on my top5 Roasters list for the Bay Area! 

A must try for coffee enthusiasts.
author: Anthony L.

description:
don't understand the smoking thing. everyone in front of the door, sitting on the bench next to the door, sucking on tobacco cock. isn't this illegal? sidewalk has the garbage to prove it, butts littered around. i guess it's easy to notice these things because the line moves slowly. you end up wondering how to avoid getting repeatedly punched in the face by cancer. 

after the wait you get a choice of coffee, coffee or coffee. asked for a savory and heard "i don't know what that word means, point at whatever you want" response. "something without sugar" i asked instead. "point" i was told again.

drinks are said to be made locally, which really means somewhere else people did actual work. the person in front of you lifts a handle, turns a lever, and chalks that up as "making" something. if pouring is making, i'm a factory. 

spots are hard to come by in the small interior. outside an uber was parked in middle of street. traffic at a standstill. uber driver window down, meekly calling out "craig, craig". i saw opportunity. convince craig, guy slowly stirring milk into a cup (another maker, i guess) that he should go outside and get in his uber. free up a spot, free up the street. let the world move again. he laughed and said "so? yeah i'll go". 

gave up on craig. instead got tourists (a couple from DC not that group from London) to shift over to make room for my cup. anyone here from here? i mean aside from the recently moved here to work at lyft. 

this place would improve greatly if: 1) it worked to keep some bay area locals coming back. nothing makes a cafe warm and inviting like locals to set a familiar-like tone/friendliness. did not see anyone say hello or even hi. more like fisherman's wharf than a neighborhood spot. 2) enforce basic hygiene. how the smoking thing happens i can't even 3) educate staff. lacking inspiration or information they work like unhappy drones faking the making.
author: Mulberry S.

description:
When I went up to the cashier to place my order, the first thing my barista asked about was what I usually have to drink. I replied with "cold brew", and he kindly recommended a cold brew + agave nectar (i think) + almond milk. Intrigued by the new experience, I agreed and paid. 

My order came out shortly afterwards, and the drink was more or less what I had expected. It wasn't too sweet, which I greatly appreciated, and though the taste of the almond milk was a bit more than what I had wanted, it was still good. 

This location is really nice because it's only a 5-10 minute walk from other great coffee places such as blue bottle, so "barhopping" between them is definitely a possibility for anyone interested!
author: Jay P.

description:
The iced latte was on point. Smooth texture and rich flavor. $4.50

My friend said his espresso was even better than Costa Mesa's Portola Lab.

Would come here again.
author: Jeffrey Y.

description: Coffee is great, the staff is cheerful and sweet.  The ambiance is nice, sometimes it takes a minute for the coffee... But you can't rush a good thing. I like it.
author: Sarai T.

description:
I loved this look of this little cafe, from its brass light fixtures down to the leather upholstered banquette seating and "live roasting" area where you can watch beans go from green to toasty right before your eyes. 

Oh yeah I guess I should mention the coffee offerings...superb! Delicate mocha with light hint of chocolate and not too sweet. We also sampled the chorizo croissant (how could I NOT get that!? So good!) and the pear scone which was a little too dense for my taste, but then again i am scone snob (being of Scottish ancestry and all). 

Super friendly staff - that was certainly an unexpected surprise considering I wasn't even wearing the requisite Mission hipster dress code of vintage spectacles and/or tweed shoes. Thanks for being friendly despite my "normal" clothes, you nice bearded barista dude! :)  

Word to the wise: probably don't plan on camping out with your laptop on the weekends - this place was super duper crowded and people were snatching up chairs like they were life jackets on the titanic. Had to escape the mayhem so we took our treats for a stroll around the Mission.
author: Alexa R.

description: I love the cold brew coffee!! The Slight Glass is comfortable and a great place to have a conversation or enjoy a cup of coffee.
author: Jeannice S.

description: Parking here is always so tough but the service and coffee make it worth it!
author: Meg S.

description: Beautiful new space in the mission. The lighting and layout makes for a comfortable and calm environment. Any place with pour-overs is my kind of place!
author: Bree G.

description: Amazing space in a nice neighborhood. Really glad that Sightglass is closer to me in the mission. It's not as big as the on on 7th, which means it maybe hard to find a spot to sit and have your coffee and pastry. Most people don't linger her as much as they do at other spots. So if you wait you'll be able to grab a seat.
author: Theresa D.

description: I thought Third Rail and Everyman were the pinnacle of high quality caffeination until I came here.... You should consider proximity to Sightglass to be a selling point for your new condo.
author: Nicolay S.

description:
Goodness, I adore Sightglass. I'm a level-90 caffeine addict, and Sightglass is fast becoming one of my favorite places for coffee and cold brew in general. Honestly, do yourself a favor and skip overrated Blue Bottle and head straight for Sightglass.

The 20th St location isn't the famous 7th St location but still a lovely space. Right off of Florida and 20th St, it's in a quiet, yet trendy block of Mission next to American Grilled Cheese Kitchen, Atlas, Central Kitchen, and others. Sightglass is so lovely, with lots of plants, wood, and beautifully showcased pastries.

My favorite thing to get here is the vanilla cold brew/iced vanilla toddy, which has housemade vanilla syrup- which isn't very sweet actually, but quite vanilla-y, housemade cold brew, and milk of your choice, I really like almond milk. I tend to like quite sweet coffee, but this really hits the spot, even though it's not really very sweet at all. It's just so aromatic and the coffee itself is soooo smooth and not at all acidic, just the way I love my cold brew.

Pro-tip: If you get the coffee in-house, they'll give it to you in an adorable mason jar which is much larger than their to-go cup. It's a lovely place to sit and soak in the sun. No wifi and slightly limited seating, but there are tons of restaurants nearby.
author: Kate M.

description: I had a vanilla cold brew with almond milk and it was good. But the vanilla with regular milk was even more amazing. I hate being lactose intolerant.
author: Fernilla S.

description: Really great coffee, made a stop there while visiting San Francisco. Not much of an atmosphere to work in due to lack of seating. Cool spot to grab something to go though. They really let you see their roasting process and shows that everything is done on site. It's a hipster hot-spot for sure, so if that's what you're in to...
author: K L.

description: Meh. Don't see what all the excitement is about. Interior is nice. Staff is cool. The coffee is not outstanding though.
author: luis m.

description: This new location is a bit out of place and small. While the coffee is quite good, there are not a lot of tables and no WiFi or outlets, so be warned. It's a good place to meet up with friends, but perhaps not the most ideal for studying.
author: Michelle Y.

description: Good coffee and nice environment at the trade off of no wifi, limited seating, and rude, unsympathetic staff.
author: Kitty C.

description: Decent coffee that doesn't compensate for the pretentious staff. I will say that the space is beautiful and also well known, so a decent meeting spot for a walking meeting
author: Joel W.

description:
Good coffee, they roast more on the light to medium side for drip. Standard espresso for the rest. 
Way more flavorful than others I've had recently. 
Like other reviews, seating is a little odd. Decided to soak in rare clear sunny skies in SF.
author: George K.

description: Very elegant and airy coffee shop. Everything in there is very artistic and you can even see design in the cups! (well, you can always buy some coffee paraphernalia at their shopping shelves, all super cute). Cappuccino done perfectly. I like the whole minimal look, but it would be nice to have more space to sit, even outside. Definitively better than Starbucks or any other chain.
author: Carmen V.

description: A nicer than the average bear coffee shop. The variety of edible goodies is great and the shop itself is nice.
author: Rodger R.

description: Tried an vanilla iced toddy! Super yummy, definitely stands alone great, no sugar needed! I guess it's categorized as an iced latte, but it was more of an iced milk with a little coffee flavor. It was still good though! Cute cups and awesome space. The booth side seats were really cool. I loved the vintage feel of it. The decor is really applaudable here. I don't really recommend doing work in here by the way. They had this, assumably, coffee machine churning something and and it's a little loud.
author: Holly P.

description: Best coffee in San Francisco. Searched everywhere and stumbled across this amazing coffee house. Definitely worth the find.
author: Breishen S.

description:
Delicious coffee and a very nice staff.  They have your selection of pourover, espresso and drip brewed en mass.  This location, just off Mission is in a more residential section so it looks like a mostly locals place.

The seating area is small and students seemed to linger while we were there.  Good luck getting a seat to enjoy your joe.
author: Vinny P.

description: Made my almond milk latte perfectly. And the lady taking my order asked me how my day was going which I must admit, took me by surprise since many people don't do this anymore. Love the ambience and limited seating. It's not really a place for studying if that's what you're looking for. There is a huge bench outside which was perfect for the day I visited. The new cups are SUPER adorable too!
author: Liliana P.

description: After seeing the good reviews for this place, we decided to come to try it! My friend and I both got the latte and I really like it. It was the right amount of bitterness and boldness. I also got a chocolate chip cookie which I would have to say is one of the best I've ever had! Overall, I'm pretty satisfied and will definitely come back again sometime!
author: Katelyn P.

description:
9.4.14: decided to give it another shot. The guy at the register so not friendly. Since the hand made coffee menu looked like it changed I wasn't sure  what to get. Seems like this shop upholds the ideals for employees to be snobby. After I ordered my coffee one of the girls asked what I was waiting for. Seriously, guy takes my order and walks to bathroom after and doesn't tell anyone my order? Do people here not know how to smile? It's just another too cool for school hipster spot. Down to 1 star. Definitely not coming back. I'll stick to my Stumptown coffee across the street at Atlas Cafe. 

Some time the last week of August: 
I love their turnovers and coffee BUT man....the two girls that were working today are so uptight! I almost feel uncomfortable asking then for something. The taller blonde with short hair just had a straight face. I asked her for a little almond milk and she just had this look like I was troubling her. Shouldn't people that work at coffee shops be a little friendlier? I'm almost convinced I may not want to come here too often just for the reason that it's not very welcoming. Can't they at least smile and pretend to like what they are doing?! I know it's early and all but this is your job! I don't like philz too much anymore but at least their staff is perky. Blue bottle a little uptight sometimes but way friendlier. 

Sightglass staff on 20th, get your act together. The only friendly person was the guy at the register. Get off your high horse girls.



only adding an extra star because the pastries are Delish.
author: Sheena C.

description: I had a latte and ginger scone here almost every day for months. It was always delicious and the staff is very nice!
author: Larissa S.

description: If you are not price- or time-sensitive, get something individually dripped. Otherwise, you can go for the quick cup and be on your way. I like the mugs that the coffee is served in and it can be yours for $35. The space is gorgeous both inside and out, sleek fixtures. Beans for sale here. There's also Hooker's and Mast Bros chocolates. There's a cool pastry case with delicious pastries. Of course, most importantly... the coffee is delicious and smooth.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I'd been ignorantly unaware of this location, but it's quite gorgeous - smaller than in SOMA and with a bit more of a relaxed vibe, at least in the afternoon. There was a nice selection of baked goods/sweets from Piccino, b. patiesserie, Hooker's and others (nice mix of savory and sweet stuff), and the latte was excellent as I've come to expect from sightglass. Gotta try one of the vanilla drinks next time.
author: Lisa K.

description: Coffee was great and is even better when you have it with the chocolate raspberry scone. Wish I could have stayed longer to enjoy the place, but was in a rush and got it to go.
author: Aaron C.

description: I had an iced mocha, but there was actually no mocha syrup in my coffee. I was left quite saddened. The espresso was smooth, but at the end of the day, it was not a mocha. I was also a bit confused that this place poured cold coffee into a hot coffee paper cup.
author: Danielle C.

description:
Cold brew vanilla drip with whole milk for the WIN. I wish it came in a 20 ounce cup. Had their kimchi morning roll and was not a huge fan of it. It was not NOT good it just did not taste like a breakfast item.

There was limited seating on a sunny Sunday morning but nothing to get red face and angry about.
author: Lilani E.

description: Wonderful service, the vanilla cold brew was perfect. Nice little gem of a location. Got some reading done, and the coffee shop didn't get as crowded as I had expected it to be after hearing so much about this place for a while. Also how cute is the tile work on the entry way? I must have amused the baristas and customers spending minimum five minutes trying to get the perfect shot of it, oh boy LOL
author: Nadine C.

description: My favorite iced coffee, second only to telescope. More mild than Philz, more flavorful than bluebottle, not as bitter as ritual, More convenient than st. Frank,better location than Trouble/coconut, Less earthy than mr espresso and more local than peets. A little pricey but worth it.
author: Frank S.

description: Sightglass is not only one of the most beautiful cafes I have been to, but they also make the best almond lattes a person can find! They are in a stunning building and awesome location too. The staff weren't overly friendly on the day we went in, but the ambiance made up for it. Everyone must go here at least once! I didn't want to leave.
author: H T.

description: While the space itself is lovely, the seating cramped and limited and no WiFi is available (by no means necessary, but certainly a bit limiting with what one can do here).  Definitely much more suited to being a quick stop to grab a quality pour over or espresso drink and be on your way.
author: Eric F.

description:
The wife and I cruised here after a tasty lunch for an afternoon jolt. This location is a lot smaller than the SOMA location, but they still manage to roast coffee here and serve up a great espresso.

We chilled here for a bit and that's about it.
author: Jerry H.

description:
It seems that in San Francisco your coffee allegiance tends to fall to but a handful of roasters. Mine, for the short times that I'm in the city and should I ever live there, would fall to Sightglass (and maybe one or two more).

I was eager to venture to their new cafe space and wasn't disappointed when a friend and I arrived on a Sunday morning. The high-ceiling space was bustling with people from all walks of life enjoying a common drink. Natural light, Scandinavian-inspired interior make it a truly pleasant spot to spend a while sipping coffee and chatting with friends.

My cappuccino was at Sightglass' usually high standard and the brioche sweet Danish was a grand breakfast dessert!
author: Lani P.

description: So excited to see this open up nearby.  But now I have to choose between sightglass and blue bottle or walk several more blocks for ritual and linea.  The staff here is super friendly and really gives you the neighborly vibe.  For their grand opening they had coffee on the house.  One guy seemed to be getting upset since the was trying to pay for his drink and no one was helping him.  Then they asked him what he ordered, and he listed different espresso drinks in which the staff replied, "coffee is on the house today, welcome to sightglass."
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place out ever since it opened! The design of their coffee cups were cute and I'd seen a lot of people around the neighborhood with their coffee. Needless to say, they did not meet my expectations.

For half the size of a regular coffee cup, you get to pay $4 for an iced coffee. What a great deal!! NOT. When I saw the size of the cup as the worker was pouring my coffee, my jaw must've literally dropped. $4 for that measly thing?!!? Not only was the price RIDICULOUS, the taste was meh. It reminded me a little too much of Blue bottle (which I am not such a huge fan of in the first place), but Blue bottle was way better.

Also, the worker that took my order wasn't extremely friendly. Although he wasn't outright rude or mean, I'm always a little thrown off when service-industry-related workers don't make it their responsibility to be nice to customers. 

You know when you rate 2 stars, yelp describes that as, "Meh. I've experienced better."?? Couldn't have said it better myself.
author: Hannah K.

description:
This is a beautiful space to enjoy a coffee. Warm, well appointed and lovely. 

I was greeted by the tiled flooring promising "COFFEE", which is pretty much what every inch of my body was screaming while suffering the jetlag of a 19 hour timezone difference from my beloved coffee hub of Melbourne. 

Opting for the filter coffee (or 'individually prepared' seems to be the terminology used for pour over here), I was given a very large mug of delicious Columbian coffee.

While browsing the Yelp reviews, I noticed all the outrage over this place not having wifi. It's not a workspace, but a retreat to relax over a coffee for a few minutes. A little downtime never hurt anyone.
author: Mel P.

description:
New place in my immediate hood wedged between Salumeria and Atlas Cafe (and Trick Dog). 

Two visits and I'm done, n' 'ere's why:
- First visit: overpriced Small (served utterly lukewarm) Americano (~$4, I believe?)
- Second visit: $3.00, three-f'ing-dollars, for a SMALL, unnoteworthy pour of drip coffee. 

Since in neither case did I see the barista cupping her hands behind the arse of an Asian Palm Civet, then roasting the beans herself before handing me my cuppa, I'm inclined to go next door to Salumeria for a savory cup of French Press at a more reasonable, justifiable price point of $2.25 (and they also have amazing honey on their coffee bar.).
author: Jaime S.

description: This is the most next level coffee shop I've ever been to. The design is nailed. Has incredible architecture and design throughout. The coffee is sightglass so it's already the best. Bob Dylan on vinyl.  Yes.
author: Ryan T.

description: Beautiful space, owners are super friendly! Try their Jerboa's Jump espresso, exclusively at this location.
author: Connor M.

description: Love this new location. Checked it out on my way to Timbuk2. Cool seating - though not nearly enough. Love the floor and the ceiling, the attention to detail is beautiful and it really makes a difference in this neighborhood. Friendly staff and amazing coffee. Had an iced latte - it was a warm day - and it was incredible. Worth the $4.50 - yikes - can't do that everyday. Wish we had one in the Danville or San Ramon area - people would freak out over here in the burbs. The city gets all the cool spots :( Great work guys on opening another totally cool spot and roasting an amazing bean.
author: Taylor C.

description: Coffee is whatever and the service is the new SF mission which anyone who is born and raised bay area knows what thats turned into. The pastries that they serve there are totally wonderful but they don't make them I believe it's from La Patisserie. And last but not least don't go there to plan on working for hours they have no outlets to charge any device.
author: Hilary J.

description: Great coffee, like really good coffee. The atmosphere is great to catch up with a friend, but not so great to work. They do not have a wifi network, no outlets, and very limited table space.
author: John D.

description:
Really great space and cool vibe especially with its old school Mcintosh amp and old school speakers playing old school jams from a vinyl record player. Only problem was that my pants were so tight I couldn't jam to it. Trendsetters, bring back the Hammer pants!

The espresso I got was decent but not up there with the best I've had (Blue Bottle, Verve, Four Barrel, Stumptown). There are some places that do a great job of their espressos and I can drink them without adding any additional sugar. This was not one of them.

The mocha was much worse. It didn't give you that comforting feeling you get with a mocha. It is a sugarless mocha which is well appreciated given the over abundance of syrupy coffee drinks but it still has to be a good product to drink. This could have used a few shots of that syrup from Starbucks. The attempt at being artisinal was a fail here and the poor mocha was barely half finished.

Finally, I purchased a bag of beans. I usually check the roasting dates when buying but I failed to this time so I blame myself. The bag of beans I bought here were on their shelves seven days past roasting date. Yes, it doesn't mean the coffee isn't drinkable but it starts to lose its flavor and blooming right around that time for pour over with a dripper.
author: C L.

description:
I've tasted "peak hipness" and it's bitter, tiny, and $14 for 2 mochas. http://sfist.com/2014/02/24/second_sightglass_coffee_opens_20th.php The cup was really small and the flavor of the mocha was really bitter.

The staff was really nice, the space was super cool, and I love the design on the coffee cups...if only it was a much bigger cup for that price tag.

Between this place and another overpriced place that I gave glaring reviews to next door, I feel done with SF. Seriously, what average person can afford this place anymore and who wants to?
author: Kate C.

description: Happened to be here since my lady did an engagement shoot. First time here and the barista recommended the vanilla iced cold brew--tasty and not too sweet! It was a perfect amount of sweet. Definitely quality in the brewing. The cafe itself is also very cute. Fiver.
author: Nichole H.

description:
literally the best almond milk latte i have ever had in my life.
