also, the vanilla iced brew is crazy delicious. I've been recreating at home.
author: Sophia S.

description: Absolutely some of the most perfect coffee I've had. Cashier was sweet, baristas quiet and professional. Sometimes a roasterie such as this can have an obnoxious or snobby feel but sightglass is mellow, making it a very comfortable to hang out. We enjoyed our drinks so very much. The pastries were lovely but I do wish there was an offer to warm my croissant. We are out of towners but would love to return!
author: Suzanne M.

description:
A new cafe just opened nearby my work, so I was so excited for it. Two starts is ONLY for their coffee which is pretty good. 

BUT, I am sure I won't come back again due to their SLOOOW service. When I first time here, I waited 15mins for my latte, I understand good coffee takes time to make but 15mins ??? I don't think is reasonable and why it took that long, because the lady was busy enough to keep talking to a guy and forget about my coffee. 

Today I gave It another tried, I called beforehand to place my order for three latte, and I tell the guy I will be here in 10 mins. Okay, when I go get my coffee, the lady at the cashier told me they NEVER received my order. I was like WTF , it was happened just 10mins ago.

Well, if you don't care about your customer than why I have to come and spend my money here!!  Ever though you are only one min walk away from my work, but I'll passed and go to have my blue bottle coffee which is two block away from you.
author: Mavis L.

description: Small spot hidden away on 20th street, next to Mission Cliffs. What's really cool about this place is that they highlight different beans and roasts then their main location. This adds variety to the mix, so if the 7th street location doesn't meet your fancy there's a good chance this place will. The location is probably 1/10th the size of the main location, but it adds an air of intimacy and definitely allows you to have a better conversation with the baristas/ workers. The only downside has been that their pourover consistency lacks. Some days you'll get horribly underextraction and the next you may have a beautifully complex cup. I'll update the review as I visit the location more.
author: Nick F.

description:
The woodwork is nice -- the handmade trash can on the way to the bathroom neatly evokes pre-McCafé McDonalds. 

A welcome addition to the neighborhood.
author: James B.

description:
This place looks nice. But that's not why you go to a coffee shop. I have ordered lattes from here as well as whole beans, and neither of them are that great. The last time I went, I had a mocha. It just wasn't anything special at all and the chocolate wasn't sweet, which is why I order a mocha.

Regarding the whole beans, I bought the Cubito, Carlos Olivero beans which the website states is "an approachable, elegant, rounded cup, with creamy flavors of milk chocolate, blackberry preserves, and a soft, peach-like acidity." 

These beans were so bland. I always make my coffee in an aeropress, and I gave these beans several chances. It tasted like crappy coffee. They tasted as bad as the Mr. Espresso beans someone gave me for free to try out.

They do have good pastries and a large selection of them. There are just too many places with better tasting coffee.
author: Phoenix W.

description:
Awesome Latte packed into a tiny cup. Wish my cup wasn't so small but it was well worth paying 4 bucks for it. Friendly service and cute little sitting area as well. 

I say why not?! Beats the heck outta paying 5 bucks for Starbucks's burnt coffee.
author: Toni S.

description: Amazing place if you love taking ''hipster'' Instagram pictures! Serves good coffee and their croissant is really good!
author: Rachel H.

description:
I snuck over to this new neighborhood nook before work this morning and was not disappointed.  I have always felt intimidated by Sightglass, (as I once asked if they had dark roast and was on the receiving end of a look that insinuated I was flem-worthy).  

With its gorgeous aesthetics and coffee to cry for, I knew I had to check out this new location.  It was quaint, but gorgeous and boasted friendly staff with recommendations that roared.  I had a turnover and coffee and fell in love with both instantly (and I'm not easy when it comes to coffee, if you know what I mean).  My only recommendation is that you avoid the turnover on a date as it is flaky to perfection and is prone to sticking to red lip lipstick like paper mache.

I just may like this Sightglass better than its big brother.
author: Allyson D.

description: A brightly-lit, if uncomfortable place to wait until 8am, when Atlas opens its doors (Phew!). The espresso, music and staff are equally insipid, and the space is the least congenial excuse I have found yet for a gathering spot. An immediate improvement would be to have Atlas open an hour earlier (not that their espresso is any better, just different). Please someone have a word with them.
author: Jay B.

description: Their coffee is soooooo good. I no longer need to haul my butt to dirty-Soma to get some Sightglass. Now that my coffee addiction has returned after a 3.5 year hiatus, and this place opened up 50 yards from my home, it's a dangerous dangerous situation. Props to them for serving drinks on the house for their opening day!
author: Kazu O.

description: I stopped by with a guest on a late Sunday morning for a cup of coffee and really loved this place.  They were really friendly and provided some help in deciding which cup of coffee to try.  They did a pour-over with Colombian beans that was really well done, and a great value overall (why is coffee so much more expensive in LA?).  The space is open with a lot of nice natural light, though a few more tables would be nice.  Would recommend this place as great place to stop amongst all the choices for coffee in the Mission!
author: Eric N.

description: I like it! Not a good place to go if u like dark roasts. For that, u probably wanna go to the Philz on Cesar Chavez. The shop is inspiring. I just feel energized to sit and reflect.
author: -Young- T.

description:
I love Sightglass Coffee and the beans they roast. Perhaps I'm a bit biased in saying that I still am in love with the original Sightglass that's on 7th and Folsom because of it's amazing industrial, high-ceiling construction and it was all before there was any hype around the brand itself. 

That being said, this Sightglass location is great (gotta love the outer Mission/Portrero area!), however the seating space inside is SO limited and it's more of a get and go coffee house. The inside feel to it reminded me a lot of a mix of The Mill and the Blue Bottle at W. C. Morse, and not so much the Industrial feel I was hoping for. 

Personally though, I'd do one of two things: 1) just go to the original Sightglass location or 2) walk down a couple blocks to Heath Blue Bottle.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Great shop. Breathtakingly beautiful. Coffee is great, and it's pretty cool all the coffee for this location is roasted here on site. The fact the espresso blend served here is made for this location only gets points in my book. The pastries are great too- have you tried a pistachio croissant before? Killer.
Only downside is it's tough to get a seat. This is a small space with very few seats and they fill quickly.
author: dance f.

description: Always friendly and knowledgable staff greet me when I'm the least sociable. The atmosphere is warm and inviting. They have a really good product here.
author: Marty W.

description: The coffee was good but the pretentious barista that made my pour over coffee had nothing but contempt for me and my attempts at friendly conversation.
author: Ric C.

description: Great specialty coffee and atmosphere. Staff were helpful and friendly too. We also purchased beans from there (the one from Guatemala). Although a little pricey, the taste was worth the price.
author: X L.

description: Ordered the ice coffee and sure enough, like most coffee shops in the city, they filled up the small glass to the top with ice, then poured 1/3 of the cup with iced coffee and the rest with almond milk. It was literally maybe 4 sips of coffee. Tasted good but totally not worth the money.
author: J P.

description: Old school McIntosh amp powering some awesome vinyl. Mix that with a healthy selection of fresh roasted beans and you find coffee heaven. I went with the Ethiopian as it was highly recommended by the barista. Beans are roasted in house and rival some of the other roasters in town like Four Barrel and Blue Bottle. I feel this is one of the top roasts I experienced over the weekend.
author: Chase L.

description: Zen atmosphere and excellent coffee. The diffusion of lighting makes this neighborhood gem beautiful. The simplicity of ambiance is striking with its prominent colors - brown and white. The tables are light brown, walls are white, though tables are too close to each other, creating awkward tension. The espresso is light and refreshing with almost no acidity. Music played is of an avant garde variety. Love Sightglass.
author: Jay C.

description: Its okay. Not the greatest. The pastries are better than average but for the most part its got nothing on any of the regular mission cafes that have been around twice as long. Tiny cups of coffee...
author: Lenny K.

description: Artsy farsty decor, but extremely limited seating, mediocre iced coffee, and the worst offense of all NO WIFI. Ew.
author: Azul C.

description: The design of the interior is superlative. I love how the spaciousness still elicits a feeling of comfort. Very enjoyable spot, and the coffee is great.
author: josh a.

description: Go anywhere else! Blue Bottle, Ritual, or Four Barrel. Service was quick. This was my second time at a Sightglass facility. $20 for two very small mochas (6-8 oz) and two chocolate croissants (day old, or left out earlier) isn't great. The espresso did not stand out, and neither did the chocolate. Polite staff, I tipped them, but did not enjoy my second trip to Sightglass...avoid. Parking difficult for the neighborhood as well. I was in With another guest around 9am.
author: P S.

description: Bleh- sour tasting espresso was not that great. I like bold, roasted, not sour. I loved the ambiance but the coffee has to be rock solid. I don't think I will return.
author: Charlene N.

description: Beautiful space! They have my favorite pastries, and the coffee - as always, is superb. Welcome to the hood!
author: Jon B.

description:
The coffee is alright. The people are awful. I've never encountered worse service staff in my life. 

They are rude beyond reason.
author: Max S.

description: I had the iced coffee. It was delicious. If my review was based solely on the taste, it would have to be a 5. However, the volume of coffee for the price charged was pretty small, and the barista really crammed the ice in. More importantly to me, however, was that the service was not particularly pleasant.  In no way hostile, but also not really commensurate with a 4 dollar cup of what looks like 5 fluid ounces of iced coffee.
author: Ryan W.

description:
As a visitor from Boston, I gravitate to few great coffee places around the mission and soma. It's not that we don't have coffee or hipsters back east, but both seem to reach their highest expression here.

I visited this Sightglass by accident due to an uberx slip-up, but it's my new favorite spot. There's a feeling of serenity and community at this location, and it feels like some kind of Japanese/Scandinavian loft circa 1962. Also the coffee and pastries are excellent.

There isn't a ton of seating, so this isn't the best place to come read/write/linger for hours. I'm also surprised that all the best coffee shops seem to use the same bakery, though from the quality it makes sense why.
author: John O.

description: Sightglass Coffee is a hipster-y little coffee place -- serving a variety of pastries, espresso drinks and of course, pour over coffee. I don't think this is the coffee place for one to settle down and get work done (nope, not Atlas Cafe). It's definitely more of a place to relax, take a break, and enjoy your company (if you have one). I'm especially smitten with the floor tiles at the entrance, which spells "COFFEE". Indeed, they do serve coffee.
author: Cassy H.

description: Beautiful and comfortable space designed by Boor Bridges Architects.  The coffee is superb.
author: David B.

description: Our go to coffee place with a bike (as it is a little off the beaten track). Does a perfect flat white and there is an outdoor bench that you can drink your coffee on which is always in the sun. Quick hassle free service.
author: Livia M.

description: It was a great experience coming here even though I always avoid going to the Mission. The store was clean and it has great interior design, simple but very pretty. Staffs were super nice and friendly. Our drink came out shortly after ordered. It was a Sunday afternoon, so the place was a little bit crowded, so we cramped up on the bench outside which was fine as well. It was a good time here (thanks to the one who suggested this place)
author: Zisele N.

description:
Let's give them 5 stars! They deserve them:)
I go there a couple of times a week to get my almond milk latte and it is consistently delicious... The place is beautiful and spacious. The barristas are nice. Their selection of pastries is the best in the city... ok, so there is no wifi... big deal! Do you remember the times before the Internet? People would actually socialize in cafes and read books... I love my computer just like most of us... but when I enter some of the hipsters' cafes and see 90% of the patrons glued to the screens of their shiny Apple computers... it makes me nostalgic for the good old times when SF was more about people and art and conversation and less about money and apps...   and I will drink my coffee to that! ;)
author: ania w.

description: $5 for a 10 oz mocha that tastes like a bitter latte?!?! H-E-double-hockey-sticks no! I wandered in the door because it seemed like a good place to get my morning coffee before heading off to work. My standard order to gauge the coffee-ability for a cafe is a mocha. Other than the name, Hooker's Mocha, there was nothing positive about the drink. There was absolutely no taste chocolate taste in the entire 10 oz cup. Oh and did I mention that cost $5? I know coffee prices are going up but $5 for the size of a cappuccino? I think not. That $ 0.75 overage compared to Philz could go towards my dessert fund. Let me know if you want to contribute. =)
author: Gwen L.

description: This was our first visit. I ordered their house mocha and a pistachio/blackberry croissant. The staff was friendly and the interior clean and well lit. The mocha was smaller than the size served in most coffeehouses. It was barely sweetened with a complex, pleasing flavor, and attractively presented.... There just wasn't much of it. The croissant was excellent, with perfectly balanced flavor and textures.. However, the two items set me back a full $10... Pretty pricey. The least costly baked good was $3.50 and some of the servings were what I'd call tiny. I should comment, I'm a reasonably skilled baker myself and can say that too many of these baked items were priced way too high for the cost of creating them. While my experience was satisfactory, I likely will not come here again due to the high cost and small servings. Also... No Wi-Fi, which was disappointing.
author: Deborah R.

description: Great quality coffee. Big fan of their lattes ($4) and it comes with an artistic design (I tipped them ahead and got a cool teddy bear). They use some unique beans and the interior is spacious. I think their coffee menu has under 10 options, and that's a good thing as they probably do those 10 drinks well. I'd come back if i'm in the Mission.
author: Chuck N.

description: Loved the coffee and perfect coffee house atmosphere. Music can be better though. Good baristas.
author: Santhosh Kumar B.

description: Coffee was mediocre and overpriced, service was that we're-doing-you-a-favor indifference and it generally has a tone/look/vibe of walking on the set of a movie that's satirizing then blindingly pretentious foodie/hipster (fipster?) scene.
author: bob h.

description: It's a beautiful new space. You gotta love Sightglass for the beans they roast themselves. This is not the original Sightglass that's on 7th and Folsom but also has industrial, high-ceiling space with lots of nice details.
author: ari s.

description:
This was my first time coming here. As I entered, I knew this was not going to be your typical Starbucks/Peets experience nor was it going to be like Blue Bottle either.  Decor is very clean and open. Looks like they sell a few pastries, there's a small nook for folks to sit with their electronic gear oh...and beverage of choice.  I walk up to the counter and I let the cashier know that this is my first time here.  She greets me with a smile and hands me the menu.  She proceeds to tell me a few things of what they have and don't have, but I am not familiar with the lingo and she's talking pretty quickly.  I proceed to ask her, "so are these the different kinds of flavors of coffee you have now?" She proceeds to explain and is talking pretty quickly again.  So finally I tell her, " I'm sorry. I didn't understand a word you said. I'm a novice at this and if you can please give me a little more clarification and explanation on what you have."  So now she speaks slower and goes more into detail what the different sections of the menu are.  I finally state, " oh ok so do you also serve ice coffee or ice tea?"  Finally she peaks my interest on a drink called Vanilla Iced Toddy made with almond milk.  Loved it! 

My advice is for all folks in customer service is never assume who you're customers are and to speak slower than sounding like a machine gun because you want to just get thru explaining your products. I've worked in customer service and still am. There was only myself and a gentleman in line. This whole experience stressed me out and I almost walked out.  First impressions will make you or break you.

Before I forget 4 stars for the iced coffee and 3 stars for customer service.
author: Carolyn S.

description: After hearing amazing things about Sightglass coffee, I was excited to check out their new Mission location with my boyfriend this weekend.  It is a great location right new Central Kitchen and Flour and Water.  They have only been open a week, and am hoping that they haven't gotten on point.  To be fair I tried the mocha, which is not what they are known for.  It tasted like a watered down hot chocolate without the sugar.  You could not identify any coffee or sweetness.  My boyfriend ordered the drip coffee which was the way to go if I ever go back.  We did order two baked good items that were tasty; the kimchee popover and a spinich empanada.  The layout of the coffee shop is a little odd, the coffee bar has tons of room, but very limited seating for the customers.  I think they may be deterring people from working on their laptops and taking up space.
author: Victoria O.

description: Meh, overpriced, nothing special. Overpriced boutique coffee, nice selection of savory and sweet pastries, but not enough seating. Discriminates against diabetics as there is no sweetener except sugar. They do have gluten free pastries but no Splenda or other artificial sweetener. This seems to be a theme among the newer high end coffee shops, this is not the only one. Is it because they only want natural products? I mean refined sugar is not good for us and caffeine is a DRUG.
author: Gary G.

description: Looks cool as you walk in, workers are weighing and packing away coffee sacks like they just came in from the bean plantations-the smell of roasting coffee is exhilarating!!  High ceilings, cement floors and open seating arrangements make this coffee store not-so-cozy but lots of techies and hipsters bundled up against the counters anyway with their MacBooks. Great coffee as well!
author: Kalong W.

description: This is my absolute favorite place for coffee in all of San Francisco! The space is so neat and the staff are always friendly (and super hip!). The pastries are from a separate vendor and are exceptional. This place is a hidden gem!
author: Nathan L.

description: Lovely little shop. Not a large number of seating, but beautiful and comfortable setting. The service were great and the coffee and pastry are at par with their other location. A nice alternative location, if you are into Sightglass coffee and not able to make it to the SOMA location. Definitely recommend to try out.
author: J Y.

description: Cool coffeeshop with excellent coffee and the best affogato outside Italy! Recommend.
author: R H.

description:
The front door and wood ceiling are amazing!  The staff seemed nice.
The latte was run-of-the-mill and the pastries were overpriced for what they were.  I was also a bit disappointed by the lack of choice when it came to the dairy -- whole milk and almond milk only, and not having a sugar alternative.  I know they're going for the 'all-natural' appeal, but it's shortsighted and naive.  I was there with someone who is type 1 diabetic.  I happen to know a few friends that are.  No, they shouldn't have to carry around their own splenda, stevia or whatever most coffee shops have.  If you're going to go outside the norm, then please advertise at the door or register in some way that imperfect people must bring their own common coffee condiments.  There are many better coffee shops that are hospitable to a broader real world clientele.  I've now been to a couple coffee shops like this and I just ask that they get off the all natural high horse.  If you think the coffee you serve only tastes good with whole milk, almond milk and canned sugar, then you need to keep working on your blend.
There were 5 or 6 other customers in there already, and so there was no where to sit.  Lame.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: A go-to when we're in the city. It's so conveniently located unlike the other location, with food next door and more room for people. Love the shared back area with salumeria. And their barista Danny is pretty rad
author: Christina p.

description: Coffee was good and the shop itself is a huge, cool space... The cashiers were snobby, the coffee menu is limited, plus they only have one menu printed so you can't look at it in line if there is anyone in front of you in line who wants to look at it... Which kind of made for a unnecessarily weird/awkward interaction.
author: j a.

description: Good coffee and the SOMA space has decent service. I've taken several friends to this Mission location and they all each commented on the unfriendly, borderline rude service.  They serve good coffee at Atlas, Coffee Bar and Blue Bottle nearby.
author: Ingrid L.

description: The place would deserve five stars for the pastries and coffees that are amazing but one star for the attitude of the people working there and the kind of customers. So maybe just going to get pastries and coffees to take out and enjoy somewhere else is the best arrangement for me
author: Luca R.

description: Nice, fresh and open space.  The coffee is of good quality and staff are friendly.  But the resistance of Sightglass to Wifi is bizarre.  Particularly when at this location and in Soma every other person is asking about Wifi.  The staff must really get tired of explaining that they don't have it.  You have a cafe full of people with laptops looking for Wifi, but Sightglass has really taken a stand against it.  I still go once in a while because they are convenient and I really do like the staff, but the owners' conception of this place as some kind of salon for conversation or well, I am not sure what, has fallen short.  Their patrons are mostly people arriving alone and working on their laptops or looking at their phones while drinking coffee.
author: Marco C.

description: It's been quiet and empty in the mornings when I've stopped by. When you take note of the spacious interior, the minimalist decor and the superior coffee quality, it makes for a great place to sit and talk with a friend.
author: Bruce H.

description: i walked by this place a few days a week for over a year and marveled at the time they were taking to get it right, all the custom-made fixtures, the beautiful tile floor -- the tile entrance is so lovely.  and yet...i now walk in and walk right out.  there's something odd about it, user unfriendly. maybe it has to do with there being two or three times more work space than customer space -- the walkway behind the counter is so wide, and there really isn't a lot going on.  and the later is so oddly configured, almost like it was an after-thought.  you are almost forced to be in someone else's face when you sit down, and forget reading a book or paper as you'll feel guilty taking up space.  i'd rather go way out of my way to visit the 7th street location (a long walk, so not often) , or even sit in philz thrift-store castaway furniture.  either at least gives you some space.
author: Kevin G.
